comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content: This is *the* Ferris Wheel, the original built by George Ferris.

comment.author: 84195101@N00
comment._content: Man, that's cool. Anyone know how high it was?

comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content: 265 feet high. The Board of Trade Building at 320 feet and the Masonic Temple at 302 feet were taller, but that's about it. Here's an awesome illustration of comparative height, from 1894.

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: That is a great illustration - thanks for shooting that over, we had not seen it!

comment.author: 84195101@N00
comment._content:
Man, awesome illustration.

In the UK, wheels seem to be the 'big thing' in cities at the moment. Mostly off the back of the successful London Eye, I reckon. Funny to think that the idea has been around a long while though!

comment.author: 83979593@N00
comment._content: I went to the London Eye shortly after it went up - very cool, I must say...very crowded too :) I didn't realize that wheels were going up in other places over there. On our side of the pond, the Astroland closure is somewhat worrisome, but the NYT is saying the Wonder Wheel will at least stay open...for now. -shelley

comment.author: 84195101@N00
comment._content: Yep, wheels are common tourist attractions now. On a small scale, The WTA company offer off-the-shelf wheels, which are installed in Manchester, York, Greenwich (also in London), and soon in Belfast, Great Yarmouth and Windsor. See WTA wheels. On the bigger scale the Great Wheel Company have built wheels in Singapore (currently the world's biggest), and are planning wheels for Bejing, Orlando and Berlin. There are even proposals to build a wheel in Baghdad! [ref].

comment.author: 82967752@N00
comment._content: We had a wheel here in Bristol, England a couple of years ago. I just love 'em, Mr Ferris should get a medal!

comment.author: 30965952@N02
comment._content: I've taken these photos and put them into their proper geographical order here. Now you can pretend as if you were actually walking around the fair.

comment.author: 84195101@N00
comment._content:
@Newsburglar that's pretty cool! 

We should see if we can figure out the rough co-ordinates of the photos and add flickr geotags...

comment.author: 29056926@N02
comment._content: Newsburglar, that's great work. Thank you for sharing and I'm looking forward to the next installment. Maybe you saw the comments I left on photos from the wheel. In one of them I pointed out which direction H H Holmes' World's Fair Hotel used to be (I had to dig back through the book to find the cross streets). I tried taking photos from Brooklyn, Smithsonian, and a few other sites, and push them into Photosynth. I was hoping there was enough overlap that I'd be able to pan around the court of honor at least. So far, no luck (it just came up in clumps), but I'm sure there are enough photos out there somewhere to get this done without a bunch of crazy CG. Here's an example of Photosynth from some photos I took from the Washington Monument.

comment.author: 41081991@N06
comment._content:
Did you guys notice that the cars looked like long, big boxes with windows?
It had both seating and standing capacity of over 2000 people at one time...
Its height was doubled the nowadays Navy Pier one.
And the World's Fair location was around the now Science and Industrial  Museum which is south of Chicago on 57th street near Lake Shore.
(The Science Museum structure is part of the then World's Fair Main Building...)

comment.author: 25211872@N05
comment._content:
Does anyone know that this very Ferris wheel was next used during the 1904 Worlds Fair in Saint Louis Missouri ? 
 Sadly after the fair no one wanted it and it was too heavy to ship back to Chicago. They used most of it for scrap metal and then all that was left was the Axel weighing hundreds if not thousands of pounds so they actually Buried it somewhere here in St Louis .
 Mr Ferris , the man that had invented it, felt that he was a failer, since no one wanted it after the 1904  Fair in St Louis . He died never knowing that his invention would bring so much pleasure to people all around the world. 
 I will add more details about the St Louis Worlds Fair and the Ferris Wheel later .

comment.author: 40766325@N06
comment._content: Some years back workmen found the concrete footings for the wheel while excavating on the campus of the University of Chicago. After the fair Ferris wanted to build a beer garden with the wheel as the centerpiece, but the idea flopped and the wheel was dismantled and sold. It was erected again for the 1904 St Louis Fair, (Where Teddy Roosevelt's daughter Alice was one of the riders), but after that fair closed the wheel was sold for scrap. It is rumored that several of the structural members survive to this day as parts of various bridges.

comment.author: 37233792@N08
comment._content: Thanks for the update AliceFan1! I'd love to see a piece of it somewhere....

comment.author: 40766325@N06
comment._content: Several ornate railings, streetlights, and benches from the 1893 fair still exist around Chicago, as does the elevated line used to ferry visitors out to the fairgrounds. I've heard rumors that up until a few years ago, at least two of the cars from the wheel still existed, put to other purposes like a diner, or private home. When a cousins of mine company was hired to do some dredging in the former Grand Lagoon, they brought up coins and Fair related trinkets visitors in 1893 must have dropped overboard from the gondolas that took you to the Fine Arts and other buildings on the Grand Court.

comment._content: How cool. The ferris wheel was George Ferris' answer to the Eiffel Tower. There was major concern that this structure would not endure the high winds known for the area, especially a major storm that blew through during the fair. It stood better than most of the buildings. Nice creative commons piece.
